section.label: DefinitionFunction
section.title: Definition of a Function
section.p: In this section, we will definine a function and learn how to identify the input and output variables of graphs, tables, diagrams, and equations.

statement.p: A function is a relationship between two variables where every input corresponds to exactly one output.

section.p: Below, in and we have two examples of relationships which are functions. Notice that each input A, B, and C is mapped to exactly one output value. Two inputs can share the same output value, but each input must have a unique output value.

For example; in the first diagram, , each input is going to a different output value. In the second diagram, , inputs B and C are both going to the same output value of Pear, but each input is still going to a single output value.
In contrast, the diagrams below are both examples of relationships that are not functions. There is an input which has two different outputs in each diagram.
In the first diagram, , input B is going to both output values of Apple and Pear. In the second diagram, , input A is going to both output values of Apple and Grape.

Depending on the situation, we may refer to the relationship between a function and its inputs and outputs as a mapping, a correspondence, or a rule. We also have several ways to represent functions. We can use a table, a graph, a diagram, or an equation.
So far we have seen functions represented as diagrams. Before we can move on the others, we need to learn about function notation.

statement.p: The representation of a function y=f(x) is called function notation. The letter f is the name of the function, and the letter x is the input variable, and the letter y is the output variable. We say that y is a function of x.

section.p: Let's look at some examples showing function relationships using function notation.

statement.p:
In the first diagram, , we could use function notation to represent the same relationship:
f(A) = Grape. "The input A is mapped to the output Grape."
f(B) = Apple. "The input B is mapped to the output Apple."
f(C) = Pear. "The input C is mapped to the output Pear."
We would first need to name the function f as it was not given a name in the diagram.
The number of visitors, V, to the Omaha Zoo is given by the function V = g(t), where t is the number of years since the year 2000.
In this example, the input variable is t, which represents the number of years since 2000. The output variable is V, which represents the number of visitors to the zoo. The name of the function is g.

section.label: EvaluatingFunctions
section.title: Evaluating Functions
section.p: In this section, we will use function notation to evaluate functions. We will also learn how to interpret the meaning of the inputs and outputs of a function.

introduction.p: In LO 7, we learned about polynomial functions. More specifically, we learned how to find and describe the end behavior of polynomial functions, find x-intercepts and y-intercepts, and determine their behavior (bouncing off the x-axis or crossing through the x-axis). In LO 8, we will learn about what happens when we divide one polynomial function by another.

An important question we should ask ourselves is this: Why are we focusing on division but ignoring addition, subtraction, and multiplication? Let's look at some examples, using f(x)=x^2+3x and g(x)=x^2-1.

If we add these two functions, we get...
f(x)+g(x) \amp = (x^2+3x)+(x^2-1)
\amp =x^2+3x+x^2-1
\amp =2x^2+3x-1
This shows that the result of adding two polynomial functions is just another polynomial function, and we already know how to handle polynomial functions.

The same thing happens when we subtract polynomial functions...
f(x)-g(x) \amp =(x^2+3x)-(x^2-1)
\amp = x^2+3x-x^2+1
\amp =3x+1

f(x) \cdot g(x) \amp = (x^2+3x)(x^2-1)
\amp = x^4+3x^3-x^2-3x
When we add, subtract, or multiply two polynomial functions together, what we get as a result is just another polynomial function, so we don't need any new tools to handle these.
The name rational functions is based on the root word ratio, which means fraction.
Rational functions are a special type of fraction in which both the numerator and denominator of the fraction are polynomials.

In LO 8, we will learn how to determine the long-run and short-run behavior of rational functions, we will learn how to sketch graphs from rational function equations, and we will learn how to write rational function equations from graphs.

section.label: sec-long-run-behavior-of-rationals
section.title: Long-Run Behavior of Rational Functions
section.p: In this section, we will concern ourselves with the long-run behavior of rational functions.

Consider the graph of the function
f(x)=\frac{2x(x+1)}{(x+2)(x-1)}
Just like with polynomial functions, we can imagine zooming way out on the graph, and we want a way to describe what the far left and far right ends of the graph are doing.

This shows us that, when our x-values become very large and negative, our y-values become very close to 2, and when our x-values become very large and positive, our y-values become very close to 2 as well.

Using our symbolic end behavior notation, we can write this as
\text{As } x \rightarrow -\infty, f(x) \rightarrow 2
and
\text{As } x \rightarrow \infty, f(x) \rightarrow 2.
